subject: Re: [junit] Do I need to write a test in this case?
msgSnippet: ... Don t look to us for rules about what to test. If you think it might not work, then test it. Test it, anyway, just for practice. After you gain more
messageBody:
pskvi wrote:

> Hi,
> I have to remove a line of code which is setting a value to
> ValueObject. Now how can I write a test to this particular change
> that I have to make. My understanding of testing using JUnit is to
> test the component which I am changing. But in this particular case
> I will be returning this ValueObject to some other part of my code
> where there is chance that the code may fail(though I can't see any
> chance of it as of now). I'll appreciate the group's comments on my
> doubt.

Don't look to us for rules about what to test. If you think it might not
work, then test it. Test it, anyway, just for practice. After you gain
more experience, your judgment about what to test and what's Too Simple
to Break will improve.

In the meantime, test it.

Answer this question for yourself: if you made your change incorrectly,
then how would you know? When you answer that question, there is your
test. If the answer is "I don't know", then maybe that line of code you
are about to remove does nothing useful! Is there more code that does
nothing useful? Remove it too!
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
